title.narrative: IFC / WBG privat sektor och handelsrådgivande program i Liberia
IFC/WBG Private Sector and Trade Advisory Programs in Liberia

description.narrative: The International Finance Corporation (IFC) 2019-2022 Advisory Service Program seeks to support the development of Liberias private sector through agriculture value chain development, trade facilitation, increased access to finance, and an improved business climate. Proposed interventions under this program aim to improve access to markets for Liberias budding private sector. The intervention has the following objectives within its different thematic areas. The overall objective of the IFC Private Sector Development and Trade Advisory Services intervention is to support the growth of Liberias private sector by creating new market linkages for investment in agriculture value-chain development addressing financial sector stability challenges, facilitating trade, and addressing economy-wide constraints that are hampering economic growth. The above overall objective is broken down into four specific objectives: To link agro-producers, agro-processors, and markets to increase revenue and investment. At the same time, the project will address the binding constraints that impede private sector participation in selected agricultural sectors. To reduce import and export times and costs by making processes transparent and predictable, while also improving access to markets for agribusinesses. To increase access to finance throughout Liberia and especially in rural areas by assisting the build-out of mobile banking platforms. To support the government and the private sector in reforming key indicators to attract investments and decrease challenges to operating in the private sector in Liberia.

International Finance Corporation (IFC) har sökt stöd, 6 105 263 USD (cirka 55 MSEK), för att genomföra ett privata sektorn- och handelsrådgivande program kallat "Creating, and Expanding Markets Through Agriculture Value Chain Development, Trade, Access to Finance, and an Improved Business Climate" under perioden 2019-2022 som syftar till att skapa och expandera marknaderna genom utveckling av jordbruksvärdekedjor, handel, tillgång till finansiering och förbättrad affärsklimat. Den föreslagna insatsen bygger på eller kompletterar tidigare stöd som ambassaden har finansierat för IFCs program ”Investment Climate Reform and Private Sector Development” i Liberia mellan 2010 och 2016. Det övergripande målet med den föreslagna insatsen är att utveckla den privata sektorn med särskild inriktning på att diversifiera ekonomin genom värdekedjeutveckling inom jordbruket, handelstillämpning, ökad tillgång till finansiering och förbättring av affärsklimatet.

The International Finance Corporation (IFC) has requested 6,105,263 USD, approximately 55 MSEK, to implement a private sector and trade advisory programme during 2019-2022 that is aimed at creating and expanding markets through agriculture value chain development, trade, access to finance, and improved business climate. The proposed intervention builds on or compliments previous Embassy of Sweden support to IFC Investment Climate Reform and Private Sector Development programme in Liberia between 2010 and 2016.The proposed intervention overall objective is to develop the private sector with specific focus on diversifying the economy through agriculture value chain development, trade facilitation, increasing access to finance, and improving the business climate.

participating-org.narrative: IBRD/International Bank for Reconstruction and Development/The World Bank
IFC/International Finance Corporation/The World Bank Group

tag.narrative: 8.3 - Främja utvecklingsinriktad politik som stöder produktiv verksamhet, skapande av anständiga arbetstillfällen, företagande, kreativitet och innovation samt uppmuntra att mikroföretag liksom små och medelstora företag växer och blir en del av den formella ekonomin, bland annat genom tillgång till finansiella tjänster.

8.3 - Promote development-oriented policies that support productive activities, decent job creation, entrepreneurship, creativity and innovation, and encourage the formalization and growth of micro-, small- and medium-sized enterprises, including through access to financial services.

title.narrative: Agreement between Sweden and International Finance Corporation

description.narrative: The program achieved the following in Agriculture Value Chain Development: Agreed on the priority sectors with the Ministry of Agriculture (cocoa, oil palm, and rubber). Collaborated with the IFCs Industry team on a new seed project in cocoa. Initiated assessment of government assets to identify potential investment opportunities for promotion. The program achieved the following in Trade Facilitation: Supported the drafting of implementing regulations for the new customs code. Supported the National Trade Facilitation Committee. Supported government of Liberia to formally complete the World Trade Organizations (WTO) accession process. The program achieved the following in Digital Financial Services: Finalized regulation on international remittances; Central Bank of Liberia (CBL) is in the process of incorporating the comments before publishing. Finalized the digital credit guidelines. Completed an analysis of the Agent Banking Network. Completed an assessment of National Electronic Payment Switch. Supported CBL and Liberia Water and Sewage Corporation (LWSC) in initiating dialogues to digitize bill payments (LWSC has shared a list of 100 customers that they would like to transition to CBLs ACH debit infrastructure). Rolled out capacity-building for Rural Community Financial Institutions (the section on credit unions and microfinance institutions (MFIs) remains pending due to lack of CBL capacity to handhold financial institutions. The program achieved the following in Business Enabling Environment: Completed assessment of the Liberian Business Registry (LBR), and completed process map for new and improved system; Completed the baseline assessment of Business Climate constraints and identified priority indicators. Reviewed and revised the public-private dialogue (PPD) charter. The program achieved the following in Insolvency and Debt Resolution: Collaborated with a World Bank project team on a new investment project (the Bank project will procure the IT equipment needed for the Commercial Court and Debt Court). Supported the National Judicial Conference. Worked with the Judiciary to receive the letters of request and commitment for the new project. Although several meetings were conducted, the letters were never forthcoming, so there is still a question about the level of political will and commitment for the project.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
